all_paragraphs: From our macroscopic human perspective, the Universe does not seem to be quantum mechanical. Macroscopic objects appear to us to be fundamentally localized in space and time. This is in stark contrast with their quantum nature, where properties such as entanglement, non-locality, and interference are consistently shown to occur. There are only very few instances where quantum phenomena can be observed macroscopically, such as, for example, in superconductors and superfluids. But quantum properties are indeed predominant mostly at microscopic scales of energy and matter.

In quantum mechanics, as will be described at length, matter has wave properties. More specifically, a particle with mass m and momentum p = mv (where v is the velocity) has a wavelength λ = h/p where h is the so-called Planck constant. To show how quantum properties are undetectable for macroscopic objects, consider the following example given in the book by Cohen-Tannoudji, Diu, and Laloe. The wavelength associated with a dust particle (which has a diameter of around 0.001 millimeters) moving at a speed of 1 millimeter per second is of the order of 10⁻¹⁶ m (or one divided by ten thousand trillion) which is indeed negligible on the length scale of the dust particle.

Physicists, therefore, first developed classical, or non-quantum, theories. The figure above illustrates the four possible domains of physics which depend on the size and speed of the system being investigated.

A consistent implementation of gravity, more specifically general relativity (GR), into a quantum-mechanical (QM) framework is arguably the most important unsolved problem in physics today. The difficulty is that general relativity and quantum mechanics have extremely different mathematical and conceptual structures. The former is based on geometrical properties of a smooth spacetime while the latter is fundamentally probabilistic and based on uncertainty principles according to which there is a fundamental limit to the precision with which one can measure certain physical quantities.

Following Kiefer, we may divide the primary motivations for quantizing gravity into three subtopics: the successes of other unification schemes, unanswered questions regarding both the physics of black holes and cosmology, and the so-called problem of time.

Quantum field theory (QFT) is the combination of classical field theory, special relativity, and quantum mechanics (see Fig. 2) and it is one of the most experimentally successful theories of modern physics. QFT unifies all non-gravitational forces into a single framework. Since all known particles couple to gravity, its inclusion in this framework seems at least plausible.
In a letter to his friend, the mathematician Marcel Grossman, Einstein made the following remark:
“It is a glorious feeling to discover the unity of a set of phenomena that seem at first to be completely separate…”

According to the famous Penrose–Hawking theorems, singularities are inevitable in GR (under reasonably mild conditions — see Barrow). Examples of singularities are the ones inside black holes and in the birth of the Universe. The quantization of GR could eliminate such divergences.

Time in ordinary quantum mechanics is absolute and external to the physical system. Quantum field theory incorporates special (not general) relativity, and the flat, Minkowski spacetime substitutes the absolute, external time of standard quantum theory.
In contrast, time (more precisely, spacetime) in general relativity is not fixed but it is, instead, dynamical. Unifying GR and QM, therefore, is likely to lead to a new, different concept of time.

Since unifying quantum mechanics and general relativity would force us to express gravity in the quantum-mechanical framework (or the opposite), we are confronted with the so-called “problem of time”.

Hence, to understand how gravity can, in principle, be quantized, we must first investigate the mathematical and physical structures of classical (the top row boxes in Fig. 2) and quantum mechanics (the bottom row boxes in Fig. 2).

In 1687, Isaac Newton published his Philosophiæ Naturalis Principia Mathematica, better known as the Principia, arguably the most influential book in the history of science. In the period 1905–1915, Albert Einstein generalized Newtonian mechanics with the publication of his special and general relativity papers.

As explained in detail in one of my previous articles, there are two reformulations of Newtonian mechanics that make it more mathematically elegant and powerful: the Langrangian and Hamiltonian approaches.

Let us know shift gears and dive into quantum mechanics.

In the short period of 1925–1926, with the publication of seminal papers by the Austrian physicist Erwin Schrödinger and the German physicist Werner Heisenberg, the era of quantum mechanics began and the new theory replaced its classical counterpart as the more fundamental framework to describe Nature. Their work was based on previous discoveries by several other physicists, including Planck, Einstein, Bohr, and De Broglie.

The fundamental notion in the quantum-mechanical framework is the concept of a quantum physical state (see Fradkin). Mathematically, it is represented by a ray in a vector space called the Hilbert space of quantum states. Two normalized vectors or pure states ψ₁ and ψ₂ belong to the same ray if the following condition is obeyed:
(see, for example, Weinberg). A unit sphere in the Hilbert space of a quantum system (such as for example, the Bloch sphere) contains the set of all pure states with norm 1.

The importance of qubits is that they are the basic units of quantum information (quantum computers encode information as qubits).

The so-called correspondence principle between classical and quantum theories, states that physical systems obey quantum-mechanical laws, and classical physics is an approximation valid for large objects or, more specifically, large quantum numbers. The process of transition between both frameworks is known as quantization.
In the canonical quantization procedure, the canonical pair of coordinates (q,p) from classical mechanics become the position and momentum operators in Hilbert space:

It should be noted that this universality of the SE is restricted to pure states. For a mixed state, which is a statistical ensemble of pure states, the SE is replaced by the von Neumann equation. In Hilbert space, a mixed state is represented by a density operator ρ

Where did we get [the Schrödinger’s equation] from? Nowhere. It’s not possible to derive it from anything you know. It came out of the mind of Schrödinger, invented in his struggle to find an understanding of the experimental observations of the real world.
Nevertheless, one can establish some properties that the equation should obey. Those would give us at least some restrictions about its form (see Messiah for a more detailed account).

II. The paths contribute equally in magnitude. but the phase of their contribution is the classical action […]; i.e., the time integral of the Lagrangian taken along the path.

Complex numbers were already used (see Yang and Barbour) in classical physics but merely as a convenient tool. At the end of the calculations, the real or imaginary part of the result is always taken. As Yang observes, “physics was conceptually in terms of real numbers.”
In quantum mechanics, however, complex numbers are foundational. Many quantum-mechanical laws are intrinsically complex. I will now describe a few important examples.
Consider a classical electromagnetic plane wave moving along the x-axis (see Stack, on which this section was based).
The electric field (component) with a frequency of oscillation ω reads:
where ω > 0. The first and second terms are, by convention, taken to be the “positive frequency” and “negative frequency” parts respectively.

In contrast to classical electromagnetism, the sign of the frequency must be positive in quantum mechanics (there is no “negative frequency” component). Let us understand why. In one of his miracle year papers, Albert Einstein explained the photoelectric effect and showed that the energy and frequency of a light photon are related by

This relation was later shown not to be obeyed exclusively by photons. For example, consider the traveling wave associated with a free massive particle, say, an electron. Since the free electron’s energy is always positive,

so is its frequency. An example of the mass-energy equivalence relation is shown in the figure below. The energy of a photon (in this case, an invisible gamma-ray) is converted to mass in accordance with Eq. 80.

Furthermore, Louis De Broglie, in his 1924 thesis, where he suggested that massive particles also behave as waves, showed the following relation between the wave vector and the momentum of a particle:

“The fundamental idea of [my 1924 thesis] was the following: The fact that, following Einstein’s introduction of photons in light waves, one knew that light contains particles which are concentrations of energy incorporated into the wave, suggests that all particles, like the electron, must be transported by a wave into which it is incorporated… My essential idea was to extend to all particles the coexistence of waves and particles discovered by Einstein in 1905 in the case of light and photons.”

This phenomenon is known as wave-particle duality. As briefly mentioned in the introduction, this duality is usually not detectable for macroscopic objects due to their extremely short de Broglie wavelengths.
The Davisson–Germer experiment, where a diffraction pattern was observed when electrons were scattered by the surface of a crystal, confirmed the Broglie’s wave-particle duality hypothesis.
Quantum waves describing a single free particle, therefore, would have the following form:

Though the sign of the frequency part of the exponent does not change, the x-dependence of the momentum part does. It determines the direction of motion. A plus sign in the second exponential factor corresponds to a wave traveling in the positive x-axis.
Correspondingly, a minus sign is associated with a wave traveling in the negative x-axis.
These observations about the direction of motion and the fact that ω is positive imply that the wave function Ψ of a free particle is intrinsically complex.

Tensor FieldsIf associated with each point on a manifold there is a tensor, a tensor field is defined. The figure below shows a simple example, that of a vector field on a sphere in Euclidean space.

A tensor at a manifold point P is not defined on the manifold. It is, instead, defined in a plane tangent to the manifold at P. Hence, in curved spacetime, tensors at different points cannot be subtracted tensorially since they “live” in different tangent planes (see Poisson for more details).

In other words, subtracting tensors at different points does not result in a tensor. The concept of differentiation must, therefore, be redefined. The new type of derivative is called a covariant derivative and it involves the operation of parallel transport.

In general relativity (GR), the geometry of spacetime is gravity. The rigid spacetime of special relativity with flat Minkowski metric line element becomes dynamical. This occurs because matter and energy distort the geometry of spacetime. The generalized metric element can be written as follows:
where g is the metric tensor. In the case of flat Minkowski space, the metric tensor g reads:

The Einstein field equations (EFE) which establish the connection between the spacetime geometry and the distribution of matter and energy within it, are expressed in terms of tensors. Tensors are important in general relativity for several reasons, as discussed, for example, in Penrose. The main one is the fact that the EFE equations obey the principle of general covariance. According to this principle, the form of the laws of physics (in the present case, the equations of general relativity) should be invariant under arbitrary coordinate transformations. This makes sense since, as noted above, coordinates are only artificial labels. Hence they are not fundamental, and the laws of physics should be invariant under such relabeling.

Tensors are key in writing the equations of general relativity because a tensor equation has the property that if it is true in one coordinate system, it is true in all coordinate systems. Quoting Einstein, in one of his general relativity papers:

“The fundamental idea of the general covariant theory is this: — With reference to any co-ordinate system, let certain things (“tensors”) be defined by a number of functions of co-ordinates which are called the components of the tensor. There are now certain rules according to which the components can be calculated in a new system of co-ordinates, when these are known for the original system, and when the transformation connecting the two systems is known. The things herefrom designated as Tensors have further the property that the transformation equation of their components are linear and homogeneous; so that all the components in the new system vanish if they are all zero in the original system. Thus a law of Nature can be formulated by putting all the components of a tensor equal to zero so that it is a general covariant equation; thus while we seek the laws of formation of the tensors, we also reach the means of establishing general Covariant laws. “

The birth of modern cosmology occurred when Einstein published his paper “Cosmological Considerations on the General Theory of Relativity” which considered the physics of the entire Universe. In this article, Einstein postulates that the Universe has a closed spatial geometry, more specifically that of a three-dimensional sphere, finite in space but yet unbounded. However, to find a solution to his field equations, he had to introduce a new term, the Λ term in the EFE.

Canonical quantum gravity (CQG) is a general effort to develop the quantum version of the Hamiltonian formulation of general relativity. In this procedure, one can use different canonical variables. Here I will treat the most straightforward strategy, known as geometrodynamics or the initial value formulation of general relativity (loop quantum gravity is a popular alternative). It can be defined as “an attempt to describe spacetime and associated phenomena solely in terms of geometry […] and reformulate general relativity as a configuration space of three-metrics”.
But before considering geometrodynamics in its “full glory”, I will consider, following Atkatz, a very simple case.

Consider a closed Universe (k=1), “born from nothing” with constant vacuum energy density only. With this choice of parameters, the Friedmann equations describe the so-called inflationary phase. In this phase, the Universe expanded at an exponential rate.

In the general case, the spatial part of the metric, or 3-geometry, does not have all symmetries of the FLRW-type universes. As a consequence, the argument of the wave function of the universe Ψ is not a single function — a(t) in the FRW case — but a set of functions that describe the 3-geometry. More specifically, Ψ becomes a functional instead of a function (a functional takes a whole function and returns a single number) defined on superspace which is the configuration space of general relativity, the space of all 3-geometries. In the maximally symmetric case of the minisuperspace approximation, we only need to take into account a subsection of superspace.

The Wheeler-DeWitt equation has some noticeable features that distinguish it from the Schrödinger equation.

TimelessnessThe first one is the absence of the time coordinate: the wave function of the universe Ψ depends only on the spacelike three-geometry (this gives origin to the “problem of time” mentioned in the introduction). This is due to the diffeomorphism invariance of general relativity (or equivalently, its general covariance), which implies that a particular (external) time coordinate should not be present in the equations (see Hamber).

One can also understand the Ψ dependence as follows (see Kiefer). In quantum mechanics, the notion that a particle has a well-defined trajectory q(t) is meaningless and it is replaced by the probability of finding the particle at a particular position q at time t. Therefore, in the Schrödinger equation, the wave function should not depend on q(t), but only on q and t separately. Making the analogies h ⇔ q and g ⇔ q(t) and recalling that absolute time does not exist in GR, the replacement of q(t) by q and t is equivalent, in gravitational physics, to the replacement g ⇒ h. This justifies why only 3-space remains (instead of four-dimensional spacetime) in the argument of Ψ.

The WdW Equation Is Real Instead of Complex as SEThe second significant difference is that the Wheeler-DeWitt equation is real in contrast with the Schrödinger equation (SE) which is complex. The problem is that, according to our discussion in the second part of this article, time and the imaginary unit i are essentially inseparable. This makes the disappearance of i quite puzzling.

One can recover time by separating the system into two subparts and expressing the time evolution of one of the subparts using as time a parameter from the other subpart.

Time and α-particlesThis was first noticed by the British physicist Sir Neville Francis Mott in a 1931 paper on the topic of atomic physics, where the collision between alpha-particles and atoms was investigated. In his paper, Mott used the following procedure. He first split the total system (the atom together with the colliding α-particle), into its two subparts. He then defined time using one of the subparts namely the state of the α-particle.
